candidates.title: Display progress bars for long-running operations
candidates.body:
This adds progress bars for most long-running operations using indicatif. It
also adds some support for avoiding tearing when these progress bars are used
in-tandem with tracing logging.

Progress bars or spinners will be shown for running `cargo metadata`, fetching
imported audits, acquiring contended lockfiles, and computing suggested audits.

Fixes #209

candidates.title: Update imports.lock less frequently
candidates.body:
This patch reduces the frequency that imports.lock updates by doing a
few things:

 * Imports are only updated when necessary for the vet to pass. If vet
   would successfully pass without the new audits, only changes to
   notes, criteria descriptions, revoked audits, and violations will be
   pulled.

 * Some commands, such as suggest, will always run against the live
   copy when not --locked, providing the most accurate results possible.

 * Only audits for crates in your crate graph will be imported.

 * When an update is required, all new audits for the given crate will
   be fetched and locked, to batch updates as much as possible.

This required doing some changes to how imports are handled under the
hood, as well as a number of changes to the resolver in order to track
whether fresh imports are required with sufficient accuracy. Imports are
also now fetched in more APIs in order to have the most up-to-date
information.

The changes to the resolver involved piping through "caveats" which are
determined when solving paths. This is an expansion on the existing
"needs_exemption"/"fully_audited" flags which were being used to
generate stats after a successful vet to also handle freshly imported
audits which should only be used when necessary.

Special handling was also needed to make sure that audits for unused
criteria are not counted by tracking caveats on a per-criteria basis and
bubbling them out.

Fixes #272

candidates.title: Certify Flow UX Improvements
candidates.body:
A set of wording changes to the certify flow in order to improve their clarity. The bulk of the changes here are to make sure that we release the cache and store locks before running a subshell or showing diffs when running in local mode.

This change ends up removing `ExecPanic` as we need to keep the current process around to print a message after the shell has exited.

Fixes #277 and #278.

candidates.title: namespace and map criteria properly
candidates.body:
fixes #240 in principle, but needs ALLLL the tests

This ended up being less gnarly than I expected, I especially like that it results in a bunch of duplication getting removed. 

Right now I have duped all the APIs as `criteria_mapper.blah(...)` and `criteria_mapper.namespaced_blah(namespace, ...)`. The non-namespaced version is implicitly Local. It's convenient but a potential footgun. Not sure if it should be removed in favour of all call-sites being explicit (anything from audits.toml and config.toml is always local, except for the foreign mappings themselves).

candidates.title: Report JSON errors uniformly to Out
candidates.body:
This changes the way that errors are handled and allows them to be
uniformly presented to the standard output when they're encountered.

This will also include panic errors, which should now also be reported
as error objects to the normal Output when encountered, and are
formatted using miette to fit in with other errors.

This is done by introducing a new hook which is used by cargo-vet to
report errors to the console, and handles overriding the format for json
errors. Errors printed to enter into things like logs will be presented
as normal, as logs are currently always destined for human processing.

In order to allow the `Out` object to be shared with the error reporter,
this ended up requiring the type to be wrapped in an `Arc<T>`, and for
the signatures of various methods to be changed. As the `io::Write`
base trait couldn't be used anymore, the signature of `write_fmt` was
also simplified to no longer return an error, simplifying the call-sites
of `writeln!(out` across the codebase.

Fixes #216

candidates.title: Introduce Spanned toml deserialization, add some validation/tests
candidates.body:
Spanning is done with the Spanned<T> hack from toml-rs. A bunch of serialization code had to be rejigged
to play nice with that hack. In particular things like flatten and untagged_enum make it freak out, so
now we deserialize all the fields and then pick which variant it is.

Store now records the source files it imported, and we now check that criteria names are valid everywhere.
New tests allow us to quickly check different inputs parse/fail-parse/fail-validate.

candidates.title: print errors as JSON with --output-format=json
candidates.body:
Fixes #216 

Several caveats that we can potentially hammer out now or over time:

* The errors will however still go to stderr rather than stdout, as a current artifact of the order we set things up in.
* Two major classes of errors, Audit Violations and Unvetted Dependencies, are currently treated
* Very early errors like CLI parsing will not have this format, as we cannot at that point "know" what you want
* Panics will not have this format
* I don't really know the full schema of this format at the moment, but some examples can be found in the checked in snapshots

candidates.title: Complete rework all of our error handling to favour explicit error ty…
candidates.body:
…pes over printing and Report

This is a bit hacky because it's basically a first pass. After this we can refine the code more piecemeal.

candidates.title: audit-as-crates-io v2
candidates.body:
* Makes it a part of policy
* Makes it an error to have it '= true' when the version isn't in the registry (false is fine and unchecked)
* Makes code correctly use normal_and_build_deps instead of all_deps where appropriate (handles workspace members-as-third-party)
* Removes a completely unused field from PackageNode that was an artifact of a previous refactor

candidates.title: Make suggest much more async, move cache to a platform-specific dir, and add a "vet gc" command
candidates.body:
This is unfortunately a combination of 3 seperate changes which all ended up being interdependent. Each of the changes are described below:

<details><summary>Use the 'dirs' crate to store our cache in a platform-appropriate cache directory</summary>

This is a more persistent place to write the cache than in the temporary
directory, and we'll implement a GC mechanism on top of it to clean out
unnecessary cache files over time in a later commit.

This also renames some variables to reflect that the directory is now
explicitly a cache, rather a temporary directory.
</details>

<details><summary>More aggressively make parallelizable io async</summary>

This makes all io around networking and diffing crates async, and attempts to
run things concurrently as much as possible. For example, when generating
diffstats for suggest, all crate downloads and their diffs are run concurrently
with limits to avoid too many connections to crates.io at once.

This refactor also includes some extra logic which was added to the package
fetching logic to ensure that we update the mtime on the .crate file whenever
it is accessed, so that information can be used in the next patch for GC.

To make this change, the cache needed to be made shareable across multiple
concurrent tasks. The core mutable state was moved behind a mutex, and new
tables of async OnceCells were added to ensure that only one task would attempt
to download or diffstat each crate at a time.

With these changes, the time to perform a `cargo vet suggest` on
mozilla-central with an empty cache and use of the cargo registry cache
disabled, reduced from ~18s to ~1.5s.
</details>

<details><summary>Add a 'vet gc' command to remove old packages from the cache</summary>

This command will delete any unrecognized files in the cache directory, as well
as old/out-of-date packages. In addition, a `--clean` flag was added which is
even more aggressive, removing even the diffcache and command-history.json.
</details>

Fixes #191
Fixes #132

candidates.title: WIP async downloads
candidates.body:
This rejigs a crapton of code to make all networking completely explicit and async.

To make this more tolerable, some things that randomly do networking (notably compute_suggest) have been hoisted out of methods and must now have their result passed in, keeping those parts of the code "network pure".

To keep the rest of the code logically sync/main-threaded, we now spin-up a tokio runtime whenever we have a burst of "need to do some async work". One of the nastier consequences of this is that anything that wants to be async needs to be rooted in all `'static` inputs even though we subsequently block on them, so i had to rejig some stuff to take e.g. String instead of &str or be a free function instead of a method. Some of this could be cleaned up by requiring `Arc` instead of `&`, but I'm still feeling out the design space.

-----------

This is motivated by #90, #132, and #167.

For #132, this is only a partial answer as it only parallelizes networking in places where queries are non-conflicting "by construction" and does not allow for greater parallelism in suggest by kicking off every package's suggest in parallel. In particular a "first suggest" will still be very slow because none of the git-diffing or even cache-sniffing is parallel, only the downloading.

For #167, it now makes all code "trivially" --frozen correct, as the only way to get network access is to call something that checks that flag.

For #90, it was just going to be another situation where I need to do a bunch of network-poking and so I wanted to have a better story for when/where networking can happen. To complete it (which is what this PR will do when it's complete) I will need to further factor the code to pull DepGraph construction out of `resolve` and instead make the DepGraph an *input* to resolve. This is because computing is_third_party will become a value that depends on the Network to check if a non-crates.io dep *does* exist on crates.io.

candidates.title: Switch to toml_edit to get more control over serialization
candidates.body:
This allows us to perform custom formatting behaviours in a visitor over the serialized `toml_edit::Document`. Because of this extra control, we can now make sure that dependency-criteria is rendered as an inline table, and that strings are formatted as multiline strings when they contain newlines, among other formatting changes we may want to make in the future.

This patch does not use the format-preserving features of `toml_edit`, so the output is always consistent for the same data.

Fixes #103
Fixes #155

candidates.title: Switch to cargo's infrastructure for file locking
candidates.body:
This required a copy of Cargo's logic for file locking to be copied in-tree. We should look into making it a seperate crate so it can be shared by other libraries in the future.

Fixes #146

candidates.title: migrate logging to tracing and use panics for exits
candidates.body: This is not what I intended to be doing today but there's some connection between logging and error handling, and tracing works "better" with eyre, so this was a step1 in understanding the error-handling ecosystem better.

candidates.title: Sort more things
candidates.body: r? @Gankra

candidates.title: Fix suggest/regenerated-unaudited's handling of policy failures
Certify fixups
candidates.body: r? @Gankra

candidates.title: Break cycles
candidates.body: This is a simpler version of #59 (based on top of #60 to avoid rebase issues) that on its own is "fine" and makes the tool usable but doesn't really address the *semantic* issues of cycles.

candidates.title: completely rework fetching and caching infra
candidates.body:
Fixes #55 

* We now have a single Cache struct which can theoretically acquire a global lock (not actually implemented, lockfiles can be very cursed and make things worse if you're not careful...)
* Fetches now check the cargo registry, then check our fetches, and then finally download the file
  * Check looks for a .cargo-ok file which is written only after a complete successful fetch+decompress
* Downloading the crate vaguely mimicks Cargo but with less sanity checks
  * GET the url
  * assume it's a tar.gz file and unpack to our cache
  * write the .cargo-ok file
* The diff_cache is now only loaded and written once per execution, instead of repeatedly

Since we no longer run 'cargo' during fetch/diffing, everything seems significantly more responsive. Also now *everything* feeds into this common machinery so there's less random garbage in each command since most of the details are handled by the Cache.

This doesn't handle #29.

Release notes

Tokio v1.20.1

1.20.1 (July 25, 2022)

Fixed

  • chore: fix version detection in build script (#4860)

#4860: tokio-rs/tokio#4860

Tokio v1.20.0

1.20.0 (July 12, 2022)

Added

  • tokio: add track_caller to public APIs (#4772, #4791, #4793, #4806, #4808)
  • sync: Add has_changed method to watch::Ref (#4758)

Changed

  • time: remove src/time/driver/wheel/stack.rs (#4766)
  • rt: clean up arguments passed to basic scheduler (#4767)
  • net: be more specific about winapi features (#4764)
  • tokio: use const initialized thread locals where possible (#4677)
  • task: various small improvements to LocalKey (#4795)

Fixed

Documented

  • fs: warn about performance pitfall (#4762)
  • chore: fix spelling (#4769)
  • sync: document spurious failures in oneshot (#4777)
  • sync: add warning for watch in non-Send futures (#4741)
  • chore: fix typo (#4798)

Unstable

  • joinset: rename join_one to join_next (#4755)
  • rt: unhandled panic config for current thread rt (#4770)
